title: Anker’s beefy Laptop Power Bank has returned to its Black Friday low
summary: After a quiet period post-Black Friday, Anker's Laptop Power Bank is back on sale for $87.99, matching its record-low price. This 25,000mAh power bank can charge multiple devices simultaneously and is TSA-compliant for travel. Other notable deals include the Bose SoundLink Home at $179 and Roku’s Streaming Stick 4K for $24.99. Meanwhile, the Xbox Series X is available for $599.99, a $50 discount, amidst rising prices.

title: Nvidia to license AI chip challenger Groq’s tech and hire its CEO
summary: Nvidia is strengthening its position in chip manufacturing through a partnership with Groq, an up-and-coming competitor in the sector. This collaboration is expected to enhance Nvidia's capabilities and further solidify its dominance in the semiconductor industry.

title: The year data centers went from backend to center stage
summary: Data centers have evolved from being mundane tech infrastructure to a critical focus in the tech industry. Their role has expanded significantly due to increasing demands for cloud services, energy efficiency, and sustainability. As companies prioritize data center capabilities, innovations and investments in this sector are transforming how businesses operate and respond to data needs.

title: The European startup market’s data doesn’t match its energy — yet
summary: Europe's startup market has struggled to deliver significant growth, but there are signs that this trend may soon change. Analysts suggest emerging factors could lead to improved performance as the landscape evolves, potentially fostering a more vibrant entrepreneurial ecosystem across the continent.

title: Waymo explains why its robotaxis got stuck during the SF blackout
summary: The company reported that its robotaxi fleet successfully navigated over 7,000 dark stoplights in a single day, showcasing advancements in their autonomous driving technology. This milestone reflects the increasing capabilities of their vehicles in handling complex traffic situations.

title: Waymo is testing Gemini as an in-car AI assistant in its robotaxis
summary: Waymo is currently testing a new AI assistant powered by Gemini, capable of answering general knowledge questions and managing in-cabin features. Insights were gained from a detailed 1,200-line system prompt outlining the assistant's functionalities.

title: The 9 top biotech startups from Disrupt Startup Battlefield
summary: The article presents the full list of selectees for the biotech and pharma Startup Battlefield 200 competition, highlighting the innovative ideas and technologies that led to their selection. Each startup is recognized for its potential impact on the industry, with emphasis on their unique contributions to biotechnology and pharmaceuticals.

title: Can AI fix the operating room? This startup thinks so
summary: Hospitals are losing two to four hours of operating room time daily due to inefficient coordination and scheduling rather than the surgeries themselves. The article highlights that while there is significant excitement about AI and robots in healthcare, addressing these operational inefficiencies could yield substantial savings for hospitals. Improving OR coordination could alleviate the financial strain on healthcare facilities.

title: How Mill closed the deal with Amazon and Whole Foods
summary: Matt Rogers' food waste startup is set to introduce its commercial food waste bins in grocery stores across the U.S. He emphasizes the importance of strategic planning and adaptability in preparing a startup for success. The initiative aims to reduce food waste significantly, highlighting the growing focus on sustainability in retail.

title: Apple pauses app store changes in Texas after court blocks age assurance law
summary: Apple has announced a temporary halt to its compliance efforts with a new age verification law in Texas. Despite this pause, the company reassures developers that other age-assurance technologies will still be accessible for use.

title: The 14 top agtech, food tech startups from Disrupt Startup Battlefield
summary: The article reveals the complete list of selected participants for the Startup Battlefield 200 in the agtech and food tech sectors. Each chosen startup is highlighted with a brief explanation regarding their selection, emphasizing their innovative approaches and potential impact in the industry.

title: Italy tells Meta to suspend its policy that bans rival AI chatbots from WhatsApp
summary: Italy has mandated that Meta halt its policy prohibiting companies from utilizing WhatsApp's business tools to deploy their own AI chatbots. This decision allows businesses greater freedom in integrating AI technology within the messaging platform.

title: How to track Santa Claus this Christmas Eve using AI
summary: Tracking tools like the NORAD Santa Tracker and Google’s Santa Tracker allow people to see when Santa Claus will arrive. Additionally, new AI tools have emerged to enhance the holiday experience, adding to the festive magic.

title: Trump administration’s ban on foreign-made drones starts this week — you can say goodbye to new DJI models
summary: The article discusses the ongoing competition between Chinese and American consumer tech products, highlighting recent developments that reflect this evolving conflict. It outlines how both nations are trying to gain an edge in technology and market share amidst geopolitical tensions. The rivalry continues to shape the global tech landscape.

title: ServiceNow to acquire cybersecurity startup Armis for $7.75B
summary: Armis, a prominent cybersecurity firm, is set to deliver substantial returns to its investors, which include Sequoia, CapitalG, and Insight Partners. The anticipated deal highlights the company's growing value within the cybersecurity sector.

title: Zoox issues software recall over lane crossings
summary: The company has released a software update for its autonomous driving system aimed at correcting issues related to lane-crossing behavior. This update is intended to enhance safety and improve the overall performance of the technology.

title: John Carreyrou and other authors bring new lawsuit against six major AI companies
summary: Authors have rejected Anthropic's proposed class action settlement, contending that large language model (LLM) companies should not be allowed to dismiss numerous significant claims for minimal compensation. They emphasize the importance of robust accountability and fairness in the legal proceedings concerning emerging technologies.

title: Hackers stole over $2.7B in crypto in 2025, data shows
summary: In 2025, crypto hacks and heists reached a record high for the third consecutive year, marking a significant increase in thefts within the cryptocurrency industry. This ongoing trend highlights persistent security vulnerabilities and challenges faced by crypto platforms.

title: US insurance giant Aflac says hackers stole personal and health data of 22.6 million people
summary: Aflac has confirmed a data breach involving hackers who stole extensive personal information, including Social Security numbers, identity documents, and health records. The incident has raised concerns about data security and customer privacy. The insurance company is likely to enhance its cybersecurity measures in response to the breach.

title: This founder just landed funding for a second go at the same problem: affordable custom home design
summary: Drafted, now almost five months old, presents a significant improvement over its predecessor, Atmos. The new platform addresses criticism of Atmos by focusing on user experience and functionality, offering enhanced features and better overall performance. As it continues to develop, Drafted aims to meet the evolving needs of its users.

title: Marissa Mayer’s new startup Dazzle raises $8M led by Forerunner’s Kirsten Green
summary: Mayer has launched a new company called Dazzle following the closure of her previous startup, Sunshine, which focused on photo and contact management. With Green's investment in Dazzle, the company appears well-positioned to capitalize on the emerging trend of AI-driven consumer businesses.

title: Hollywood cozied up to AI in 2025 and had nothing good to show for it
summary: In 2025, Hollywood significantly embraced artificial intelligence, particularly in post-production, utilizing generative AI for tasks like de-aging actors and removing green screens. While the technology has historically eased tedious work for artists, this year marked a shift towards more creative applications. However, concerns arose about the quality of AI-generated content, often resulting in subpar text-to-video outputs.

title: Rebellions AI Puts Together An HBM And Arm Alliance To Take On Nvidia
summary: The article discusses the proliferation of AI inference chip startups, numbering over 144 globally. It highlights Rebellions AI's strategic partnership with HBM and Arm to compete against industry leader Nvidia, aiming to carve out its niche in the competitive AI hardware market.

title: Liquid Cooling Means More Performance And Less Heat For Supercomputing
summary: The article discusses Jevons' paradox in the context of supercomputing, highlighting how advancements in liquid cooling technology lead to increased performance while simultaneously producing less heat. This suggests that efficiency improvements can result in greater usage, contradicting the expected energy savings. Such innovations in cooling are crucial for optimizing supercomputing operations.

title: HBM Supply Curve Gets Steeper, But Still Can’t Meet Demand
summary: The article by Timothy Prickett Morgan discusses the challenges in meeting the growing demand for high-bandwidth memory (HBM). It highlights that while the supply curve for HBM is becoming steeper due to increased production difficulties, it still struggles to meet the surging market demand. This mismatch between supply capabilities and market needs poses significant implications for manufacturers and consumers alike.

title: Nvidia Nearly Completes Its Control Freakery With Slurm Acquisition
summary: Nvidia is close to finalizing its acquisition of the Slurm workload manager, highlighting the ease with which anyone can take control of open source projects. The article by Timothy Prickett Morgan discusses the implications of this trend, suggesting it underscores growing concerns over corporate dominance in open source software.

title: Building The AI Factory Datacenter
summary: The article by Timothy Prickett Morgan discusses how artificial intelligence is reshaping standards and operations in modern datacenters. It highlights the concept of the "AI Factory Datacenter," emphasizing that AI influences performance metrics and architecture, ultimately transforming efficiency and capabilities in data management and processing.

title: Nvidia Is The Only AI Model Maker That Can Afford To Give It Away
summary: Timothy Prickett Morgan's article highlights Nvidia's prominence as a leading software and hardware company, particularly in the AI landscape. With around 40,000 employees, the company combines proprietary and open-source software, underlining its unique position in the industry. The article emphasizes Nvidia's ability to provide AI models at scale, despite its significant profitability and complexity.

title: Tomorrow’s Datacenter Won’t Be Like Yesterday’s – Here’s Why
summary: In "Tomorrow’s Datacenter Won’t Be Like Yesterday’s," Timothy Prickett Morgan discusses the evolving landscape of datacenter management amidst increasing demands. Organizations face pressures to adapt to new technologies and efficiency requirements, necessitating innovative planning, design, and operation strategies. The article emphasizes the need for transformation in datacenter approaches to meet future challenges.

title: How Sustainable Is This Crazy Server Spending?
summary: A recent IDC market report highlights the substantial financial investments in servers during the generative AI boom. As server revenues have surged, questions arise about the sustainability of such spending. The article by Timothy Prickett Morgan at The Next Platform visually presents the last 26 years of quarterly server revenue to illustrate this trend's impactful shift.

title: What Do You Do When You Want GPFS On The Cloud?
summary: Many AI organizations and traditional HPC centers prefer using either the open-source Lustre parallel file system or IBM's Storage Scale (formerly GPFS) for their storage needs. The article by Timothy Prickett Morgan on The Next Platform discusses the challenges and options for deploying GPFS in cloud environments.

title: Everybody But Nvidia And TSMC Has To Make It Up In Volume With AI
summary: In his article for The Next Platform, Timothy Prickett Morgan discusses the repetitive pattern in the AI industry where only Nvidia and TSMC gain significant financial benefits, while others must rely on volume sales to remain competitive. Despite this ongoing trend, reactions from the industry often suggest that the challenges posed are novel or unexpected.
